awd_titl_txt: Synthetic and Mechanistic Studies of Air-Stable Organometallic Dimers as  n-Dopants for Organic Electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY
This research project is jointly supported by the Solid State and Materials Chemistry and the Electronic and Photonic Materials Programs.  Doping of charge-transport materials can greatly improve the behavior of organic electronic devices. n-Dopants suitable for typical electron-transport materials are inevitably air-sensitive if reacting by simple electron transfer. Approaches in which air-stable precursors form dopants during, or subsequent to, film deposition can simplify device fabrication. The PIs recently demonstrated that air-stable dimers of certain sandwich compounds, such as rhodocene, can n-dope materials, forming the corresponding monomeric sandwich cations. In contrast to other air-stable precursor approaches to molecular n-dopants, side reactions are likely to be minimized and materials with much lower electron affinities (2.8 eV to date) can be doped. This proposal aims to understand the chemistry of these dimers in detail and to broaden their utility. Synthesis, NMR crossover experiments, vis-NIR monitoring of kinetics, and XPS, UPS, and conductivity studies of solution-cast films will be used to establish: the limits of doping using this approach without significantly compromising the dimer air-stability; how the rate can be controlled to permit solution-casting of films in air, with subsequent dopant activation; and the extent to which heavy-metal dimers can be replaced by related dimers of 3d-metal complexes or even all-organic dimers. 

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY
There is wide interest in lightweight-flexible electronic devices (displays, lighting, solar cells), that can be made at low cost and low temperature. These use organic (carbon-containing) molecules or polymers in place of traditional semiconductors, the electrical properties of which can be greatly improved using dopants, which increase (n) or decrease (p) the number of electrons in the material. n-Dopants are generally highly reactive, which complicates their use. The PIs have discovered n-dopants that are unusually stable, yet dope many materials. This program will enable an improved understanding and control of these dopants, related dopants, and their reactivity, and may lead to more efficient devices. Students will be trained in organic electronic materials, and, more generally, in investigating scientific problems, and case-studies will be used in the PIs' lectures. The PIs will educate and train women and underrepresented minorities by: hosting summer students and encouraging their application to graduate school, recruiting via seminars at HBCUs and other minority-serving institutions, and attending workshops and conferences with significant minority participation. The PIs' work with a NSF PREM at New Mexico Highlands University, a minority-serving institution, will be supported; students there will determine the structures of new dopants, and the PIs will give lectures linking chemistry and applications.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Organic (carbon-based) semiconductor materials have advantages of cost, processibility, low weight, and flexibility over traditional inorganic semiconductors, such as crystalline silicon and so are already finding niche applications in devices, for example, organic light-emitting diodes (OLEDs) are now commercially used in cellphone displays. Other applications such as solar power generation, especially for lightweight portable cells, may also be commercialized, and yet others, such as thermoelectric power generation (allowing waste heat to be converted to electricity) are currently in their infancy. It is becoming increasingly clear that electrical doping with molecules that can donate an electron to the semiconductor (n-dopants), or remove an electron from the semiconductor (p-dopants), can play a useful role in many of these devices by increasing electrical conductivity and/or by tuning barriers to electron transfer across interfaces. n-Dopants operating by simple electron-transfer, i.e., donation of one electron to a semiconductor molecule to make a positively charged dopant and a semiconductor molecule carrying a negative charge, that successfully dope solar cell materials, let alone those for OLEDs, are highly air sensitive, which severely complicates handling and device fabrication. A possible solution is coupling of the electron-transfer process to formation and/or breaking of chemical bonds. The PIs had previously identified dimeric organometallic compounds as attractive candidate dopants: the doping process comprises transfer of two electrons from each dimer, along with cleavage of its central carbon-carbon bond. This program aimed to increase our understanding of these dopants, learning (i) how far we could push their strength, including whether OLED materials could be doped, (ii) whether doping could be externally activated subsequent to processing, and (iii) whether we could develop alternative dimers free of expensive and toxic heavy metals.

With respect to (i) the outcome was a range of new organometallic dimers, which led to a considerably improved understanding of the factors that influence dopant strength, how dopant strength can be quantified, and how one might increase dopant strength. However, we also discovered that the doping strength estimated in this way can actually be “cheated” if photoexcitation is used; some dopant / semiconductor combinations do not react in the dark, nor are expected to do so based on doping strength estimates, yet afford a doped state in solid films when exposed to visible or ultraviolet light. This doped state is metastable; i.e., it is less stable than the undoped state but does not revert to that state. This finding greatly expands the applicability of our dimers and has been successfully used in OLEDs.

With respect to (ii) we have found several dopant / semiconductor combinations that do not react in solution in the dark, but do so in light, as well as the OLED-relevant system noted above where light exposure in the solid state leads to doping contrary to dopant-strength based expectations.

With respect to (iii) we have developed all-organic analogues of our organometallic dimers; these exhibit a similar range of dopant strengths and doping behaviors, although they are somewhat less stable to air.

Broader impacts included support and multidisciplinary training of a graduate student, and partially support for another graduate student and a postdoc. Other students, both with the PIs at GT and in collaborating groups, contributed to the work and were exposed to the concepts involved, including a summer undergraduate student. Students at New Mexico Highlands University (NMHU, a minority-serving institution) determined crystal structures of dopants and their precursors. Examples from dimer dopant chemistry were used to illustrate the PIs’ classes at Georgia Tech, as well as lectures given by the PIs at NMHU

Collaborations were initiated with many groups in the US and beyond involving use or study of the PIs’ dopants in many applications including: doping organic semiconductors; modifying the properties of other materials including electrode materials, such as metal oxides and metals, and low-dimensional materials, such as graphene, carbon nanotubes, and few-layer metal chalcogenides; and applying them in other devices such as the recently developed lead halide “perovskite” solar cells. We have also made our dopants more widely available by partnering with Sigma-Aldrich who now market two Georgia Tech-synthesized dimeric dopants. Technologically, dopants have the ability to improve the performance of organic semiconductor devices including OLEDs, solar cells, and transistors, while photochemical activation can potentially simplify device manufacture. Accordingly, several companies have expressed interested in our dimers and their applications, including Samsung GRO SAIT, who funded a one-year study on use of the dimers to modify the properties of transparent conducting oxides, which are used as electrodes for many organic semiconductor devices. 

Results of our basic chemical studies and of our collaborative studies of doping particular materials or devices have been disseminated through 14 peer-reviewed journal articles already published, with more submitted or in preparation, as well as multiple conference and seminar presentations. 


Last Modified: 08/03/2017
Modified by: Seth R Marder
